pt: {sc}hire{/sc} {sc}let{/sc} {sc}lease{/sc} {sc}rent{/sc} {sc}charter{/sc} mean to engage or grant for use at a price. {sc}hire{/sc} and {sc}let{/sc}, strictly speaking, are complementary terms, {sc}hire{/sc} implying the act of engaging or taking for use and {sc}let{/sc} the granting of use.

pt.t: we {it}hired{/it} a car for the summer
decided to {it}let{/it} the cottage to a young couple

pt: {sc}lease{/sc} strictly implies a letting under the terms of a contract but is often applied to hiring on a lease.

pt.t: the diplomat {it}leased{/it} an apartment for a year

pt: {sc}rent{/sc} stresses the payment of money for the full use of property and may imply either hiring or letting.

pt.t: instead of buying a house, they decided to {it}rent{/it}
will not {it}rent{/it} to families with children

pt: {sc}charter{/sc} applies to the hiring or letting of a vehicle usually for exclusive use.

pt.t: {it}charter{/it} a bus to go to the game
